Limit sodium to less than 2300mg daily

explanation.main_explanation: Based on the symptoms provided, our system assessed a 95.0% risk level for hypertension with HIGH confidence. This assessment is for informational purposes only and should be discussed with a healthcare professional for proper evaluation and guidance.

educational_content.about: Hypertension (high blood pressure) is a condition where blood pressure is consistently elevated.
educational_content.risk_factors: Age, family history, obesity, high sodium intake, and lack of exercise increase risk.
educational_content.prevention: Maintaining healthy weight, reducing sodium intake, regular exercise, and limiting alcohol can help.

confidence_reasoning.meaning: The system has high confidence in this assessment
confidence_reasoning.recommendation: We strongly recommend consulting with a healthcare professional for proper evaluation
confidence_reasoning.reason: The symptoms strongly align with patterns associated with this condition

explanation.text: Based on the symptoms provided including increased thirst, frequent urination, fatigue, there is a medium probability of Diabetes.
Based on the symptoms provided including headache, dizziness, chest pain, there is a low probability of Hypertension.

Based on the symptoms provided including headache, dizziness, chest pain, there is a high probability of Hypertension.
Based on the symptoms provided including fever, body aches, fatigue, there is a high probability of Influenza.

foods_to_include: Vegetables and fruits (DASH diet emphasizes these)
Whole grains (brown rice, whole wheat, oatmeal)
additional_tips: DASH diet is highly recommended for hypertension
Read food labels carefully for sodium content
Cook at home to control sodium
supplements: Discuss magnesium, potassium (only under medical supervision)
diet.hydration: Adequate water intake; limit alcohol consumption
diet.meal_timing: Regular meal schedule helps maintain stable blood pressure

specialist_visits: Cardiologist if BP difficult to control
screenings: Blood pressure checks regularly (home and clinical)
preventive_care.regular_checkups: Regular primary care visits (initially monthly, then every 3-6 months when stable)
monitoring_at_home: Daily or regular blood pressure monitoring

exercise.medical_clearance: Consult doctor before starting - medical clearance essential
precautions: Avoid heavy weight lifting or straining (Valsalva maneuver)
Monitor blood pressure before and after exercise initially
Avoid exercise if BP is very high (>180/110)
progression_tips: Start with 10-15 minutes if new to exercise

sleep_hygiene.bedtime_routine: Create a relaxing bedtime routine 30-60 minutes before sleep
sleep_hygiene.avoid_before_bed: Avoid caffeine 6 hours before bed, alcohol 3 hours before, large meals 2-3 hours before
sleep_hygiene.sleep_environment: Keep bedroom cool (60-67Â°F), dark, and quiet
sleep_hygiene.physical_activity: Regular exercise helps sleep, but not within 3 hours of bedtime
sleep_hygiene.sleep_schedule: Aim for 7-9 hours of sleep per night with consistent sleep/wake times
sleep_hygiene.disease_specific: Consistent sleep schedule can help regulate blood pressure
sleep_hygiene.screen_time: Limit screen exposure 1-2 hours before bedtime
